title: How to Adjust a Cake Recipe for High Altitude

methods.name: How to Adjust A Recipe's Baking Process for High Altitudes

steps.headline: Prepare your cake pan by greasing the inside of the pan and then either dusting it with flour or lining it with parchment paper.
steps.description: This prevents the cake from sticking, which is more likely at high altitudes. The exception to this rule is any type of sponge cake, which should be baked in a pan that has not been greased.

steps.headline: Fill the prepared pan only 1/2 full instead of 2/3 full with the cake batter.
steps.description: This prevents the cake from overflowing in the pan when the air expands.

steps.headline: Increase the recipe's baking temperature by 15 to 25 degrees.
steps.description: This helps prevent the cake from collapsing.

steps.headline: Reduce the recipe's baking time by 20 percent.
steps.description: This prevents over-baking or burning. Judge your cake's rising time if yeast is an ingredient, watching it closely instead of relying on the recipe's time. Yeast can rise more quickly in high altitudes.

methods.name: How to Adjust A Recipe's Ingredient Amounts for High Altitudes

steps.headline: Substitute solid shortening such as lard, which holds more liquid, in the place of margarine.
Add in an extra egg, if egg is an ingredient, in the cake recipe.
Avoid over-beating the eggs with a whisk to avoid adding too much air.
Reduce baking powder, if present in recipe, for each teaspoon or milliliter decreasing by 1/8.
Reduce sugar, if present in recipe, for each cup or milliliter by 1/16.
Increase liquid, if present in recipe, for each cup or milliliter by 1/8 or 1/4.
